issue.title: Labels removed after rollback

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

issue.body:
Output of `helm version`:
$ ./linux-amd64/helm version
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.13.1", GitCommit:"3547a4b5bf5edb5478ce352e18858d8a552a4110", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.20.8"}



Output of `kubectl version`:

$ kubectl version
Client Version: v1.28.3
Kustomize Version: v5.0.4-0.20230601165947-6ce0bf390ce3
Server Version: v1.27.3



Cloud Provider/Platform (AKS, GKE, Minikube etc.): 
Private cloud


1. Install a chart with -l parameter. The lab is added to the release secret as expected:

[cinek@localhost helm313]$ ./linux-amd64/helm install -n ncms -l profile=myprofile test helloworld-go-1.3.47.tgz 
...
[cinek@localhost helm313]$ kubectl get secret -n ncms sh.helm.release.v1.test.v1 -o json|jq '.metadata.labels'
{
  "modifiedAt": "1698231264",
  "name": "test",
  "owner": "helm",
  "profile": "myprofile",   <-- my label added here
  "status": "deployed",
  "version": "1"
}

2. Upgrade the release with new parameter - the label is propagated to the new revision as expected:

[cinek@localhost helm313]$ ./linux-amd64/helm upgrade -n ncms test helloworld-go-1.3.47.tgz  --set aqq=sdf
...
[cinek@localhost helm313]$ kubectl get secret -n ncms sh.helm.release.v1.test.v1 -o json|jq '.metadata.labels'
{
  "modifiedAt": "1698231469",
  "name": "test",
  "owner": "helm",
  "profile": "myprofile",  <-- my label preserved in revision 1
  "status": "superseded",
  "version": "1"
}
[cinek@localhost helm313]$ kubectl get secret -n ncms sh.helm.release.v1.test.v2 -o json|jq '.metadata.labels'
{
  "modifiedAt": "1698231469",
  "name": "test",
  "owner": "helm",
  "profile": "myprofile", <-- my label propagated to revision 2
  "status": "deployed",
  "version": "2"
}

3. rollback the upgraded release - label not propagated to the next revision

[cinek@localhost helm313]$ ./linux-amd64/helm rollback -n ncms test
Rollback was a success! Happy Helming!

[cinek@localhost helm313]$ kubectl get secret -n ncms sh.helm.release.v1.test.v3 -o json|jq '.metadata.labels'
{
  "modifiedAt": "1698231681",
  "name": "test",
  "owner": "helm",
  "status": "deployed",
  "version": "3"
}
'profile=myprofile' label is missing in v3.

--------
I'd expect the labels added in v3 to be the same as in v1. Also, it think adding '-l' parameter to the 'rollback' command would be also useful. If I mark my rollbacks with a special label I could find which revisions are rollbacks just by checking the secret (no need to run and parse helm history).

Marcin

comment.body:
Hi,

I sent a PR for this issue: https://github.com/helm/helm/pull/12529.
I also sent a post on #helm-dev slack channel.

Marcin

pull_request.title: Fis for Labels removed after rollback #12521
pull_request.body:
<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
1. Make sure to read the Contributing Guide before submitting your PR: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
2. If this PR closes another issue, add 'closes #<issue number>' somewhere in the PR summary. GitHub will automatically close that issue when this PR gets merged. Alternatively, adding 'refs #<issue number>' will not close the issue, but help provide the reviewer more context.-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:
refs #12521
This is a proposed solution for issue #12521:
1. Fix the problem of missing labeling in the rollback release secret. The labels are copied from the rollback target release.
2. Adds new proposed parameter '-l' for helm rollback operation so new labels can be added to the rolled-back release or existing ones can be modified.

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

**If applicable**:
- [ ] this PR contains documentation
- [*] this PR contains unit tests
- [ ] this PR has been tested for backwards compatibility

issue.title: Using the Helm SDK when no kubeconfig is available

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Denotes an issue that needs help from a contributor. Must meet "help wanted" guidelines.

issue.body:
Currently when using helm SDK, a `RESTClientGetter` is needed. This is trivial when a kubeconfig file is available. However when the program only have access to the CA, token/certs and url in memory, it becomes a bit more complicated. 

In fact the program needs to implement the following interfaces:
- `ToRESTConfig() (*rest.Config, error)`
- `ToDiscoveryClient() (discovery.CachedDiscoveryInterface, error)`
- `ToRESTMapper() (meta.RESTMapper, error)`

Of course it can still be done with some magic, but then it is also needed to create a new abstraction over the namespace with the `ToRawKubeConfigLoader()` method. 

A fix would be to add a `Namespace` field to the kube client in order to lighten a bit the custom implementation written to use Helm3 without a kubeconfig

comment.body:
Unstale.
I am facing the same problem now.
We have created a rest.Config from (env/kubeconfig/user input) in the beginning of the program. Now we have to pass the kubeconfig file to other module because helm SDK need it (While we already pass the rest.Config). But it seems that helm client only need rest.Config and namespace info,  the kubeconfig file itself is not necessary.

issue.title: range can't iterate over .Values getting from dict
issue.body:
Hello, Basically I have a values in value.yaml
```
cloudProvider: gcp

skaResources:
  storageClasses:
    aws:
      gp2:
        isDefaultClass: "false"
   azure:
     default:
        isDefaultClass: "true"
  gcp:
    standard:
        isDefaultClass: "true"
```
in temaple 

```
{{- $cloudsTypes := dict }}
{{- $_ := set $cloudsTypes "aws" ".Values.skaResources.storageClasses.aws" }}
{{- $_ := set $cloudsTypes "azure" ".Values.skaResources.storageClasses.azure" }}
{{- $_ := set $cloudsTypes "gcp" ".Values.skaResources.storageClasses.gcp" }}

{{ range $name, $value := ( get $cloudsTypes .Values.cloudProvider ) }}

apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
kind: StorageClass
metadata:
  name: {{ $name }}
  annotations:
    storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class: '{{ $value.isDefaultClass }}'
{{ end }}
```
When I try to generate template I got

Error: template: resources/templates/storageclass.yaml:12:52: executing "resources/templates/storageclass.yaml" at <.Values.cloudProvider>: range can't iterate over .Values.skaResources.storageClasses.gcp

Can you help me? Thanks

issue.body:

Add toSeconds function to convert duration to seconds.
Add toMilliSeconds function to convert duration to milliseconds

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

It's related to #11974

issue.title: Helm upgrade doesn't uninstall old resource properly
issue.body:
Hi Dear Experts,
I am currently trying to install a Knative Service via helm charts.

I want to use a helm value(as below "knativeService") to control whether to deploy a Knative Service or a normal deployment + normal service.
When the "knativeService" is equal to "true", it will deploy knative Service, otherwise, it deploy a normal deployment + normal service.

However, during the switch( I am using the command: **helm upgrade -i** ), it will stuck at uninstall knativeService.

It seems when using Knative Service, there is an ExternalName type k8s service will be created. When I switch to a normal k8s deployment, it will also try to create a k8s service which has the same name as previous ExternalName service.

This caused the Knative controller confused and reporting error. And thus, the Knative Service CR cannot be uninstalled successfully: Similarly, If I want to switch from normal k8s deployment to Knative Service, still go problems.

But I can do helm uninstall first, then try to do install. This would properly switch.

**So I am wondering:**
**1. What is the mechanism for using "helm upgrade"? Does it uninstall unnecessary old resource first, then try to install the new resource?** 
**2. Is there a way to guarantee the upgrade workflow's order to make sure the unnecessary resources got delete first?**

Appreciate any suggestions!


Below is my helm template:

```
---
{{ if eq .Values.knativeService "true" }}
apiVersion: serving.knative.dev/v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.serviceName }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      annotations:
        autoscaling.knative.dev/maxScale: "5"
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: {{ $container }}
        image: {{ $registry }}/{{ $container }}:{{ (tuple $scope ( index $imageVersionsList $i)) | include "imageVersion" }}

{{ else }}
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.serviceName }}
spec:
  selector:
    app: {{ .Values.serviceName }}
  ports:
    - name: http-web
      port: 80
      targetPort: {{ default "80" .Values.servicePort }}
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: {{ .Values.serviceName }}
  namespace: {{ .Values.namespace }}
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: {{ .Values.serviceName }}
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: {{ .Values.serviceName }}
    spec:
      terminationGracePeriodSeconds: 10
      containers:
      - name: {{ $container }}
        image: {{ $registry }}/{{ $container }}:{{ (tuple $scope ( index $imageVersionsList $i)) | include "imageVersion" }}
        imagePullPolicy: "Always"

{{ end }}

```

comment.body: This issue has been marked as stale because it has been open for 90 days with no activity. This thread will be automatically closed in 30 days if no further activity occurs.

issue.title: unexpected status from HEAD request on push (3.13.0 & 3.13.1)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

issue.body:
Output of `helm version`:

```
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.13.1", GitCommit:"3547a4b5bf5edb5478ce352e18858d8a552a4110", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.20.8"}
````

Output of `kubectl version`: n/a

Cloud Provider/Platform (AKS, GKE, Minikube etc.): AWS public ECR

---

Since Helm 3.13.0 (including 3.13.1), we receive HTTP 400 when pushing the Helm chart on the OCI AWS ECR public repository that prevent us to release new Helm chart version.

The HTTP 400 error is not reported in AWS Cloudtrail, which suggests that the query was rejected early.

Full logs:

```
helm registry logout public.ecr.aws # optional cleanup

aws ecr-public get-login-password --region us-east-1 |helm registry login --username AWS --password-stdin public.ecr.aws

helm package configs/helm --app-version 0.2.3-rc3 --version 0.2.3-rc3

helm push --debug <our-repository>-0.2.3-rc2.tgz oci://public.ecr.aws/<repository>

WARN[0000] reference for unknown type: application/vnd.cncf.helm.chart.content.v1.tar+gzip 
WARN[0000] reference for unknown type: application/vnd.cncf.helm.config.v1+json 
DEBU[0000] checking and pushing to                       url="https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:0d2ec2c0f851156ef2efe939fa35ed5cb739e868525818e20bafebfeee119368"
DEBU[0000] checking and pushing to                       url="https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:7af1085958bd4086125c09f442d0c98c004f880794ed0fd3a7f508d4e45eadc0"
DEBU[0000] do request                                    request.header.accept="application/vnd.cncf.helm.config.v1+json, */*" request.header.user-agent=Helm/3.13.1 request.method=HEAD url="https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:7af1085958bd4086125c09f442d0c98c004f880794ed0fd3a7f508d4e45eadc0"
DEBU[0000] do request                                    request.header.accept="application/vnd.cncf.helm.chart.content.v1.tar+gzip, */*" request.header.user-agent=Helm/3.13.1 request.method=HEAD url="https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:0d2ec2c0f851156ef2efe939fa35ed5cb739e868525818e20bafebfeee119368"
DEBU[0000] fetch response received                       response.header.content-length=80 response.header.content-type="application/json; charset=utf-8" response.header.date="Thu, 12 Oct 2023 16:09:12 GMT" response.header.docker-distribution-api-version=registry/2.0 response.status="400 Bad Request" url="https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:7af1085958bd4086125c09f442d0c98c004f880794ed0fd3a7f508d4e45eadc0"
DEBU[0000] fetch response received                       response.header.content-length=80 response.header.content-type="application/json; charset=utf-8" response.header.date="Thu, 12 Oct 2023 16:09:12 GMT" response.header.docker-distribution-api-version=registry/2.0 response.status="400 Bad Request" url="https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:0d2ec2c0f851156ef2efe939fa35ed5cb739e868525818e20bafebfeee119368"
DEBU[0000] unexpected response                           body= resp="&{400 Bad Request 400 HTTP/2.0 2 0 map[Content-Length:[80] Content-Type:[application/json; charset=utf-8] Date:[Thu, 12 Oct 2023 16:09:12 GMT] Docker-Distribution-Api-Version:[registry/2.0]] {} 80 [] false false map[] 0x14000ba4300 0x1400055e0b0}"
DEBU[0000] unexpected response                           body= resp="&{400 Bad Request 400 HTTP/2.0 2 0 map[Content-Length:[80] Content-Type:[application/json; charset=utf-8] Date:[Thu, 12 Oct 2023 16:09:12 GMT] Docker-Distribution-Api-Version:[registry/2.0]] {} 80 [] false false map[] 0x140009e2200 0x1400055e0b0}"
Error: unexpected status from HEAD request to https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:0d2ec2c0f851156ef2efe939fa35ed5cb739e868525818e20bafebfeee119368: 400 Bad Request
helm.go:84: [debug] unexpected status from HEAD request to https://public.ecr.aws/v2/<our-organization>/<our-repository>/blobs/sha256:0d2ec2c0f851156ef2efe939fa35ed5cb739e868525818e20bafebfeee119368: 400 Bad Request
```

<details>
<summary>If it helps, here are the logs of a successful push in version 1.10.3</summary>


We could push with 1.10.3, 1.11.0, 1.12.0, but not with 1.13.0+.

As a workaround, we downgraded to 1.12.0.

Let us know if we may help for the troubleshooting.

commits.message:
Revert "fix(main): fix basic auth for helm pull or push"

This reverts commit 4a27baaffc7ae112c2f45e3cd72dd249d9563a5a.

Note, PR #11129 was layered in along with this change so the revert
preserves this API addition.

Signed-off-by: Matt Farina <matt.farina@suse.com>

Merge pull request #12527 from mattfarina/revert-12237

Revert "fix(main): fix basic auth for helm pull or push"

pull_request.title: Revert "fix(main): fix basic auth for helm pull or push"
pull_request.body:
This reverts commit 4a27baaffc7ae112c2f45e3cd72dd249d9563a5a.

The change to improve basic auth support caused a regression for bearer tokens. Reverting the change until we have a well understood path forward.

Note, #11129 was layered in along with this and it has been preserved with the reversion. It added to the API and we do not want to remove that.

Closes #12491

<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
1. Make sure to read the Contributing Guide before submitting your PR: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
2. If this PR closes another issue, add 'closes #<issue number>' somewhere in the PR summary. GitHub will automatically close that issue when this PR gets merged. Alternatively, adding 'refs #<issue number>' will not close the issue, but help provide the reviewer more context.-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

Note, this was created with `git revert` rather than GitHub because it was not a clean revert due to other changes that have happened since then. The original PR being reverted is #12237.

**If applicable**:
- [ ] this PR contains documentation
- [ ] this PR contains unit tests
- [ ] this PR has been tested for backwards compatibility

labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

issue.title: range can't iterate over .Values getting from dict
issue.body:
Hello, Basically I have a values in value.yaml
```
cloudProvider: gcp

skaResources:
  storageClasses:
    aws:
      gp2:
        isDefaultClass: "false"
   azure:
     default:
        isDefaultClass: "true"
  gcp:
    standard:
        isDefaultClass: "true"
```
in temaple 

{{- $cloudsTypes := dict }}
{{- $_ := set $cloudsTypes "aws" ".Values.skaResources.storageClasses.aws" }}
{{- $_ := set $cloudsTypes "azure" ".Values.skaResources.storageClasses.azure" }}
{{- $_ := set $cloudsTypes "gcp" ".Values.skaResources.storageClasses.gcp" }}

{{ range $name, $value := ( get $cloudsTypes .Values.cloudProvider ) }}
---
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
kind: StorageClass
metadata:
  name: {{ $name }}
  annotations:
    storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class: '{{ $value.isDefaultClass }}'
{{ end }}

When I try to generate template I got

Error: template: resources/templates/storageclass.yaml:12:52: executing "resources/templates/storageclass.yaml" at <.Values.cloudProvider>: range can't iterate over .Values.skaResources.storageClasses.gcp

Can you help me? Thanks

review.body:
LGTM

Tested against bearer and basic auth flows

issue.title: helm repo update with empty repositories[] fails with error 1
issue.body:
Having explicitly configured empty list of repositories is a valid situation that should not make `helm repo update` fail.

But it does:

repositories.yaml:
```
repositories: []
```

test:
```
$ helm repo update --repository-config repositories.yaml ; echo $?
Error: no repositories found. You must add one before updating
1
```

This behavior complicates automation and actual error detection.

Full test case:

```
$ (set -x; helm version; tee repositories.yaml <<<'repositories: []'; export HELM_REPOSITORY_CONFIG=repositories.yaml; helm repo update; echo $?; helm repo list; echo $?)
+ helm version
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.13.1", GitCommit:"3547a4b5bf5edb5478ce352e18858d8a552a4110", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.20.8"}
+ tee repositories.yaml
repositories: []
+ export HELM_REPOSITORY_CONFIG=repositories.yaml
+ HELM_REPOSITORY_CONFIG=repositories.yaml
+ helm repo update
Error: no repositories found. You must add one before updating
+ echo 1
1
+ helm repo list
Error: no repositories to show
+ echo 1
1
```

pull_request.title: [upgrade]: Introduce --dependency-update argument
pull_request.body:
<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
1. Make sure to read the Contributing Guide before submitting your PR: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
2. If this PR closes another issue, add 'closes #<issue number>' somewhere in the PR summary. GitHub will automatically close that issue when this PR gets merged. Alternatively, adding 'refs #<issue number>' will not close the issue, but help provide the reviewer more context.-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:

This Pull Request introduces the `--dependency-update ` to the upgrade cmd. With this addition it will be possible to upgrade dependencies before upgrading a helm release. The argument will also be passed to the install cmd when using the `--install` argument in addition, where the flag is already present. 

**Special notes for your reviewer**:
The PR was split into two seperat PRs. For further information see:

  * #9335 
  
**If applicable**:
- [ ] this PR contains documentation
- [ ] this PR contains unit tests
- [ ] this PR has been tested for backwards compatibility

labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.
